Topic.Title: New girl here... Can you help me?

Message.Msg: Jenni, First of all I'm assuming you are who you say you are, because you might be, but it's likely you're just a sock of one of the many loser shorts who are on this board. Ok, to answer your question about spotting idiots, there are 2 camps on this board, bulls who like AMZN and think it's a good investment (such as myself), the bulls are people who actually own AMZN stock. Then there are bears, who think AMZN is priced too high and will fall. There are ways to "bet" that a stock will fall in price (such as "shorting" the stock or buying "puts"), and the bears, (also called shorts, while bulls are also called longs) use these techniques to bet that AMZN drops in price. Now, as you've realized, Amazon is a great company and you (and I) believe they have a great future. Some bears find and invent all kinds of crazy reasons that Amazon is not a good company, then call them Scamazon and such. But, as you know, they're not scamming, you order something, they send it, you can send it back, they're a good company. So they say it's over-priced, and by many measures it is. But, it's "over-priced" because it's a good company that people want to own part of. We bulls have done quite well, I bought at $136. Bears have done badly, and their frustration over-flows on this board. You asked "Do you think I should buy AMZN now?" I agree with everything David (disciplined_speculator) said. You said you have $2,500 that you want to increase for your future, but it's ok if you lose it all, and you think it will be hard not to lose money. It's easy not to lose money, just don't risk any. If you want a stock to "buy and hold", I agree that AMZN would be good, but not at this price. Do you want to be an "active trader", or do you just want to buy and look at it in 10 years? Active traders can do much better than "buy and hold" people. I first bought AMZN 3 years ago at $136. I sold some at $227, bought more at $180, sold more at $260, and I still have half my stock, but my average cost per share is minus $40. That means if it goes to zero, I've still made $40 per share for what I still own. It's fun and easy to do this, but you have to file income tax on it (unless it's in an IRA or something), and you have to spend time following it. It's a great hobby, and you could end up with a few bucks when you retire. I don't have a lot, but believe me, it's great to have a few bucks when you retire. Or you could buy a big house and rent out rooms to other gen-x people and have a positive cash flow, I don't know. If you want to "buy and hold", I'd urge you to be patient, because the lower you buy at, the more shares you can get. If you hold out for $250 you can get 10 shares, $225 you'll get 11. At your age, I don't think you really know what your investment needs are, you don't know how your life is going to play out. But still, I like AMZN for you, but wait for the right price. We'll tell you when it's a good time to buy. I was on this board ranting and raving last December when it was $180 / share.

I found this strange advice, but when I have followed it I have been rewarded, and when I didn't, I have been spanked, hard. This rule doesn't always work. In 1986 I kept waiting for stocks to drop and they just kept going up and up. So I waited while all my friends were getting rich. And then in Oct 1987 the market plunged. All my friends were poor and I was buying stocks at bargain prices. You will be rewarded for being patient.

Topic.Title: New girl here... Can you help me?

Message.Msg: It's really hard to time the market perfectly and since you're new it would be real difficult to try to buy just one stock. In an effort to keep most of your money and also make good sound solid growth, you probably want to go for a basket of goods such as a mutual fund or ETF. Look for ones that have a solid growth and invest a little each month that way you are not buying on the top or the bottom. So for example, let's say you find a mutual fund that sells for $100 a share, buy some now, and some later. The great thing about mutual funds is you can buy half shares. So for example if it goes down 50% the next time you buy another $100 worth you will be buying 2 shares. If it goes up to $150, the next time you buy, you will be buying 2/3 of a share. Individaul stocks are closer to gambling than baskets as most people get burned on them.
